parameters: \>\c[6]Yanfly Engine Plugins\c[0] has provided many plugins on
\>modifying the various battler parameters used in
\>\c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0]. Which do you wish to learn about?

<WordWrap>The base parameters, \c[4]MaxHP\c[0], \c[4]MaxMP\c[0], \c[4]ATK\c[0], \c[4]DEF\c[0], \c[4]MAT\c[0], \c[4]MDF\c[0], \c[4]AGI\c[0], and \c[4]LUK\c[0] all play a very important part of battle, yet, so very little control is given to the developer in regards to these important stats.

<WordWrap>This is the maximum health points value. The amount of health points (\c[4]HP\c[0]) a battler has determines whether or not the battler is in a living state or a dead state. If the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is above 0, then the battler is living. If it is 0 or below, the battler is in a dead state unless the battler has a way to counteract death (usually through immortality). When the battler takes damage, it is usually dealt to the \c[4]HP\c[0] value and reduces it. If the battler is healed, then the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is increased. The \c[4]MaxHP\c[0]\c[0] value determines what's the maximum amount the \c[4]HP\c[0] value can be held at, meaning the battler cannot be healed past that point.

<WordWrap>This is the maximum magic points value. Magic points (\c[4]MP\c[0]) are typically used for the cost of skills and spells in battle. If the battler has enough \c[4]MP\c[0] to fit the cost of the said skill, the battler is able to use the said skill provided that all of the skill's other conditions are met. If not, the battler is then unable to use the skill. Upon using a skill that costs \c[4]MP\c[0], the battler's \c[4]MP\c[0] is reduced. However, the battler's \c[4]MP\c[0] can be recovered and results in a gain of \c[4]MP\c[0]. The \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] value determines what is the maximum amount the \c[4]MP\c[0] value can be held at, meaning the battler cannot recover \c[4]MP\c[0] past the \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] value.

<WordWrap>This is the attack value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's physical attack power. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean higher damage output for physical attacks.

<WordWrap>This is the defense value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's physical defense. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean less damage received from physical attacks.

<WordWrap>This is the magic attack value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's magical attack power. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean higher damage output for magical attacks.
In this sample project, this is represented as \c[4]INTc\[0] for \c[4]Intelligence\c[0].

<WordWrap>This is the magic defense value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's magical defense. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean less damage received from magical attacks.
In this sample project, this is represented as \c[4]RESc\[0] for \c[4]Resistance\c[0].

<WordWrap>This is the agility value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to determine battler's position in the battle turn's order. Given a normal turn calculation formula, the higher the value, the faster the battler is, and the more likely the battler will have its turn earlier in a turn.

<WordWrap>This is the luck value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to affect the success rate of states, buffs, and debuffs applied by the battler and received by the battler. If the user has a higher \c[4]LUK\c[0] value, the state, buff, or debuff is more likely to succeed. If the target has a higher LUK value, then the state, buff, or debuff is less likely to succeed.

<WordWrap>The values for the Extra Parameters: \c[4]HIT\c[0], \c[4]EVA\c[0], \c[4]CRI\c[0], \c[4]CEV\c[0], \c[4]MEV\c[0], \c[4]MRF\c[0], \c[4]CNT\c[0], \c[4]HRG\c[0], \c[4]MRG\c[0], and \c[4]TRG\c[0], in RPG Maker MV are only able to be ever modified by traits by the various database objects. While it is flexible, \c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] does not enable you to utilize custom formulas to make things such as \c[4]ATK\c[0] and \c[4]AGI\c[0] influence \c[4]HIT\c[0] rate or \c[4]LUK\c[0] influence \c[4]CRI\c[0]tical hits. With this plugin, now you can along with a few more goodies!

<WordWrap>This determines the physical hit success rate of the any physical action. All physical attacks make a check through the \c[4]HIT\c[0] rate to see if the attack will connect. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value passes the randomizer check, the attack will connect. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value fails to pass the randomizer check, the attack will be considered a MISS.

<WordWrap>This determines the physical evasion rate against any incoming physical actions. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value passes, the action is then passed to the \c[4]EVA\c[0] check through a randomizer check. If the randomizer check passes, the physical attack is evaded and will fail to connect. If the randomizer check passes, the attempt to evade the action will fail and the action connects.

<WordWrap>Any actions that enable Critical Hits will make a randomizer check with this number. If the randomizer check passes, extra damage will be carried out by the initiated action. If the randomizer check fails, no extra damage will be added upon the action.

<WordWrap>This value is put against the Critical Hit Rate% in a multiplicative rate. If the Critical Hit Rate is 90% and the Critical Evasion Rate is 20%, then the randomizer check will make a check against 72% as the values are calculated by the source code as \c[4]CRI\c[0] * (1 - \c[4]CEV\c[0]), therefore, with values as 0.90 * (1 - 0.20) === 0.72.

<WordWrap>Where \c[4]EVA\c[0] is the evasion rate against physical actions, \c[4]MEV\c[0] is the evasion rate against magical actions. As there is not magical version of \c[4]HIT\c[0], the \c[4]MEV\c[0] value will always be bit against when a magical action is initiated. If the randomizer check passes for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will not connect. If the randomizer check fails for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will connect.

<WordWrap>If a magical action connects and passes, there is a chance the magical action can be bounced back to the caster. That chance is the Magic Reflect Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate passes, then the magical action is bounced back to the caster, ignoring the caster's Magic Evasion Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate fails, then the magical action will connect with its target.

<WordWrap>If a physical action connects and passes, there is a chance the physical action can be avoided and a counter attack made by the user will land on the attacking unit. This is the Counter Attack Rate. If the randomizer check for the Counter Attack Rate passes, the physical action is evaded and the target will counter attack the user. If the randomizer check fails, the physical action will connect to the target.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxHP\c[0] as gained HP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] as gained MP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxTP\c[0] as gained TP with a 100% success rate.

<WordWrap>The values for Special Parameters: \c[4]TGR\c[0], \c[4]GRD\c[0], \c[4]REC\c[0], \c[4]PHA\c[0], \c[4]MCR\c[0], \c[4]TCR\c[0], \c[4]PDR\c[0], \c[4]MDR\c[0], \c[4]FDR\c[0], and \c[4]EXR\c[0] are lesser used and lesser known, but are only modified by database object traits. This plugin enables you to utilize custom formulas for these Special Parameters to alter them in such a way where \c[4]MAT\c[0] can alter the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost of skills and whatnot.

Against the standard enemy, the Target Rate value determines the odds of an enemy specifically targeting the user for a single target attack. At 0%, the enemy will almost never target the user. At 100%, it will have normal targeting opportunity. At 100%+, the user will have an increased chance of being targeted.

*NOTE: For those using the Battle A.I. Core, any actions that have specific target conditions will bypass the \c[4]TGR\c[0] rate.

<WordWrap>This is the effectiveness of guarding. This affects the guard divisor value of 2. At 100% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 1.00)'. At 50% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 0.50)'. At 200% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 2.00)' and so forth.

<WordWrap>This is how effective heals are towards the user. The higher the \c[4]REC\c[0] rate, the more the user is healed. If a spell were to heal for 100 and the user has 300% \c[4]REC\c[0], then the user is healed for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This is how effective items are when used by the user. The higher the \c[4]PHA\c[0] rate, the more effective the item effect. If the user is using a Potion that recovers 100% on a target ally and the user has 300% \c[4]PHA\c[0], then the target ally will receive healing for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]MP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will require to use. If the user has 100% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will be standard. If the user has 50% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills that cost \c[4]MP\c[0] will cost only half the required \c[4]MP\c[0]. If the user has 200% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills will cost 200% their \c[4]MP\c[0] cost.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]TP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge when gaining \c[4]TP\c[0] through various actions. At 100%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge normally. At 50%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge at half speed. At 200%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge twice as fast.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from physical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from magical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>On the field map, this alters how much damage the user will take when the player walks over a tile that damages the party. The \c[4]FDR\c[0] value only affects the damage dealt to the particular actor and not the whole party. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 100%, then the user takes the full damage. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 50%, then only half of the damage goes through. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 200%, then floor damage is doubled for that actor.

<WordWrap>This determines the amount of experience gain the user whenever the user gains any kind of \c[4]EXP\c[0]. At 100% \c[4]EXR\c[0], the rate of experience gain is normal. At 50%, the experience gain is halved. At 200%, the experience gain for the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This is the agility value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to determine battler's position in the battle turn's order. Given a normal turn calculation formula, the higher the value, the faster the battler is, and the more likely the battler will have its turn earlier in a turn.

<WordWrap>This is the luck value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to affect the success rate of states, buffs, and debuffs applied by the battler and received by the battler. If the user has a higher \c[4]LUK\c[0] value, the state, buff, or debuff is more likely to succeed. If the target has a higher LUK value, then the state, buff, or debuff is less likely to succeed.

<WordWrap>The values for the Extra Parameters: \c[4]HIT\c[0], \c[4]EVA\c[0], \c[4]CRI\c[0], \c[4]CEV\c[0], \c[4]MEV\c[0], \c[4]MRF\c[0], \c[4]CNT\c[0], \c[4]HRG\c[0], \c[4]MRG\c[0], and \c[4]TRG\c[0], in RPG Maker MV are only able to be ever modified by traits by the various database objects. While it is flexible, \c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] does not enable you to utilize custom formulas to make things such as \c[4]ATK\c[0] and \c[4]AGI\c[0] influence \c[4]HIT\c[0] rate or \c[4]LUK\c[0] influence \c[4]CRI\c[0]tical hits. With this plugin, now you can along with a few more goodies!

<WordWrap>This determines the physical hit success rate of the any physical action. All physical attacks make a check through the \c[4]HIT\c[0] rate to see if the attack will connect. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value passes the randomizer check, the attack will connect. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value fails to pass the randomizer check, the attack will be considered a MISS.

<WordWrap>This determines the physical evasion rate against any incoming physical actions. If the \c[4]HIT\c[0] value passes, the action is then passed to the \c[4]EVA\c[0] check through a randomizer check. If the randomizer check passes, the physical attack is evaded and will fail to connect. If the randomizer check passes, the attempt to evade the action will fail and the action connects.

<WordWrap>Any actions that enable Critical Hits will make a randomizer check with this number. If the randomizer check passes, extra damage will be carried out by the initiated action. If the randomizer check fails, no extra damage will be added upon the action.

<WordWrap>This value is put against the Critical Hit Rate% in a multiplicative rate. If the Critical Hit Rate is 90% and the Critical Evasion Rate is 20%, then the randomizer check will make a check against 72% as the values are calculated by the source code as \c[4]CRI\c[0] * (1 - \c[4]CEV\c[0]), therefore, with values as 0.90 * (1 - 0.20) === 0.72.

<WordWrap>Where \c[4]EVA\c[0] is the evasion rate against physical actions, \c[4]MEV\c[0] is the evasion rate against magical actions. As there is not magical version of \c[4]HIT\c[0], the \c[4]MEV\c[0] value will always be bit against when a magical action is initiated. If the randomizer check passes for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will not connect. If the randomizer check fails for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will connect.

<WordWrap>If a magical action connects and passes, there is a chance the magical action can be bounced back to the caster. That chance is the Magic Reflect Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate passes, then the magical action is bounced back to the caster, ignoring the caster's Magic Evasion Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate fails, then the magical action will connect with its target.

<WordWrap>If a physical action connects and passes, there is a chance the physical action can be avoided and a counter attack made by the user will land on the attacking unit. This is the Counter Attack Rate. If the randomizer check for the Counter Attack Rate passes, the physical action is evaded and the target will counter attack the user. If the randomizer check fails, the physical action will connect to the target.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxHP\c[0] as gained HP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] as gained MP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxTP\c[0] as gained TP with a 100% success rate.

<WordWrap>The values for Special Parameters: \c[4]TGR\c[0], \c[4]GRD\c[0], \c[4]REC\c[0], \c[4]PHA\c[0], \c[4]MCR\c[0], \c[4]TCR\c[0], \c[4]PDR\c[0], \c[4]MDR\c[0], \c[4]FDR\c[0], and \c[4]EXR\c[0] are lesser used and lesser known, but are only modified by database object traits. This plugin enables you to utilize custom formulas for these Special Parameters to alter them in such a way where \c[4]MAT\c[0] can alter the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost of skills and whatnot.

Against the standard enemy, the Target Rate value determines the odds of an enemy specifically targeting the user for a single target attack. At 0%, the enemy will almost never target the user. At 100%, it will have normal targeting opportunity. At 100%+, the user will have an increased chance of being targeted.

*NOTE: For those using the Battle A.I. Core, any actions that have specific target conditions will bypass the \c[4]TGR\c[0] rate.

<WordWrap>This is the effectiveness of guarding. This affects the guard divisor value of 2. At 100% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 1.00)'. At 50% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 0.50)'. At 200% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 2.00)' and so forth.

<WordWrap>This is how effective heals are towards the user. The higher the \c[4]REC\c[0] rate, the more the user is healed. If a spell were to heal for 100 and the user has 300% \c[4]REC\c[0], then the user is healed for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This is how effective items are when used by the user. The higher the \c[4]PHA\c[0] rate, the more effective the item effect. If the user is using a Potion that recovers 100% on a target ally and the user has 300% \c[4]PHA\c[0], then the target ally will receive healing for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]MP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will require to use. If the user has 100% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will be standard. If the user has 50% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills that cost \c[4]MP\c[0] will cost only half the required \c[4]MP\c[0]. If the user has 200% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills will cost 200% their \c[4]MP\c[0] cost.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]TP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge when gaining \c[4]TP\c[0] through various actions. At 100%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge normally. At 50%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge at half speed. At 200%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge twice as fast.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from physical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from magical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>On the field map, this alters how much damage the user will take when the player walks over a tile that damages the party. The \c[4]FDR\c[0] value only affects the damage dealt to the particular actor and not the whole party. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 100%, then the user takes the full damage. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 50%, then only half of the damage goes through. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 200%, then floor damage is doubled for that actor.

<WordWrap>This determines the amount of experience gain the user whenever the user gains any kind of \c[4]EXP\c[0]. At 100% \c[4]EXR\c[0], the rate of experience gain is normal. At 50%, the experience gain is halved. At 200%, the experience gain for the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This is the maximum health points value. The amount of health points (\c[4]HP\c[0]) a battler has determines whether or not the battler is in a living state or a dead state. If the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is above 0, then the battler is living. If it is 0 or below, the battler is in a dead state unless the battler has a way to counteract death (usually through immortality). When the battler takes damage, it is usually dealt to the \c[4]HP\c[0] value and reduces it. If the battler is healed, then the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is increased. The \c[4]MaxHP\c[0]\c[0] value determines what's the maximum amount the \c[4]HP\c[0] value can be held at, meaning the battler cannot be healed past that point.

As there is not magical version of \c[4]HIT\c[0], the \c[4]MEV\c[0] value will always be bit against when a magical action is initiated. If the randomizer check passes for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will not connect. If the randomizer check fails for \c[4]MEV\c[0], the magical action will connect.

<WordWrap>If a magical action connects and passes, there is a chance the magical action can be bounced back to the caster. That chance is the Magic Reflect Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate passes, then the magical action is bounced back to the caster, ignoring the caster's Magic Evasion Rate. If the randomizer check for the Magic Reflect Rate fails, then the magical action will connect with its target.

<WordWrap>If a physical action connects and passes, there is a chance the physical action can be avoided and a counter attack made by the user will land on the attacking unit. This is the Counter Attack Rate. If the randomizer check for the Counter Attack Rate passes, the physical action is evaded and the target will counter attack the user. If the randomizer check fails, the physical action will connect to the target.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxHP\c[0] as gained HP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] as gained MP with a 100% success rate.
<WordWrap>During a battler's regeneration phase, the battler will regenerate this percentage of its \c[4]MaxTP\c[0] as gained TP with a 100% success rate.

<WordWrap>The values for Special Parameters: \c[4]TGR\c[0], \c[4]GRD\c[0], \c[4]REC\c[0], \c[4]PHA\c[0], \c[4]MCR\c[0], \c[4]TCR\c[0], \c[4]PDR\c[0], \c[4]MDR\c[0], \c[4]FDR\c[0], and \c[4]EXR\c[0] are lesser used and lesser known, but are only modified by database object traits. This plugin enables you to utilize custom formulas for these Special Parameters to alter them in such a way where \c[4]MAT\c[0] can alter the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost of skills and whatnot.

Against the standard enemy, the Target Rate value determines the odds of an enemy specifically targeting the user for a single target attack. At 0%, the enemy will almost never target the user. At 100%, it will have normal targeting opportunity. At 100%+, the user will have an increased chance of being targeted.

*NOTE: For those using the Battle A.I. Core, any actions that have specific target conditions will bypass the \c[4]TGR\c[0] rate.

<WordWrap>This is the effectiveness of guarding. This affects the guard divisor value of 2. At 100% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 1.00)'. At 50% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 0.50)'. At 200% \c[4]GRD\c[0], damage will become 'damage / (2 * 2.00)' and so forth.

<WordWrap>This is how effective heals are towards the user. The higher the \c[4]REC\c[0] rate, the more the user is healed. If a spell were to heal for 100 and the user has 300% \c[4]REC\c[0], then the user is healed for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This is how effective items are when used by the user. The higher the \c[4]PHA\c[0] rate, the more effective the item effect. If the user is using a Potion that recovers 100% on a target ally and the user has 300% \c[4]PHA\c[0], then the target ally will receive healing for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]MP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will require to use. If the user has 100% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will be standard. If the user has 50% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills that cost \c[4]MP\c[0] will cost only half the required \c[4]MP\c[0]. If the user has 200% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills will cost 200% their \c[4]MP\c[0] cost.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]TP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge when gaining \c[4]TP\c[0] through various actions. At 100%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge normally. At 50%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge at half speed. At 200%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge twice as fast.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from physical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from magical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>On the field map, this alters how much damage the user will take when the player walks over a tile that damages the party. The \c[4]FDR\c[0] value only affects the damage dealt to the particular actor and not the whole party. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 100%, then the user takes the full damage. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 50%, then only half of the damage goes through. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 200%, then floor damage is doubled for that actor.

<WordWrap>This determines the amount of experience gain the user whenever the user gains any kind of \c[4]EXP\c[0]. At 100% \c[4]EXR\c[0], the rate of experience gain is normal. At 50%, the experience gain is halved. At 200%, the experience gain for the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>The base parameters, \c[4]MaxHP\c[0], \c[4]MaxMP\c[0], \c[4]ATK\c[0], \c[4]DEF\c[0], \c[4]MAT\c[0], \c[4]MDF\c[0], \c[4]AGI\c[0], and \c[4]LUK\c[0] all play a very important part of battle, yet, so very little control is given to the developer in regards to these important stats.

<WordWrap>This is the maximum health points value. The amount of health points (\c[4]HP\c[0]) a battler has determines whether or not the battler is in a living state or a dead state. If the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is above 0, then the battler is living. If it is 0 or below, the battler is in a dead state unless the battler has a way to counteract death (usually through immortality). When the battler takes damage, it is usually dealt to the \c[4]HP\c[0] value and reduces it. If the battler is healed, then the \c[4]HP\c[0] value is increased. The \c[4]MaxHP\c[0]\c[0] value determines what's the maximum amount the \c[4]HP\c[0] value can be held at, meaning the battler cannot be healed past that point.

<WordWrap>This is the maximum magic points value. Magic points (\c[4]MP\c[0]) are typically used for the cost of skills and spells in battle. If the battler has enough \c[4]MP\c[0] to fit the cost of the said skill, the battler is able to use the said skill provided that all of the skill's other conditions are met. If not, the battler is then unable to use the skill. Upon using a skill that costs \c[4]MP\c[0], the battler's \c[4]MP\c[0] is reduced. However, the battler's \c[4]MP\c[0] can be recovered and results in a gain of \c[4]MP\c[0]. The \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] value determines what is the maximum amount the \c[4]MP\c[0] value can be held at, meaning the battler cannot recover \c[4]MP\c[0] past the \c[4]MaxMP\c[0] value.

<WordWrap>This is the attack value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's physical attack power. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean higher damage output for physical attacks.

<WordWrap>This is the defense value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's physical defense. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean less damage received from physical attacks.

<WordWrap>This is the magic attack value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's magical attack power. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean higher damage output for magical attacks.
In this sample project, this is represented as \c[4]INTc\[0] for \c[4]Intelligence\c[0].

<WordWrap>This is the magic defense value of the battler. By default, this stat is used for the purpose of damage calculations only, and is typically used to represent the battler's magical defense. Given normal damage formulas, higher values mean less damage received from magical attacks.
In this sample project, this is represented as \c[4]RESc\[0] for \c[4]Resistance\c[0].

<WordWrap>This is the agility value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to determine battler's position in the battle turn's order. Given a normal turn calculation formula, the higher the value, the faster the battler is, and the more likely the battler will have its turn earlier in a turn.

<WordWrap>This is the luck value of the battler. By default, this stat is used to affect the success rate of states, buffs, and debuffs applied by the battler and received by the battler. If the user has a higher \c[4]LUK\c[0] value, the state, buff, or debuff is more likely to succeed. If the target has a higher LUK value, then the state, buff, or debuff is less likely to succeed.

<WordWrap>This is how effective heals are towards the user. The higher the \c[4]REC\c[0] rate, the more the user is healed. If a spell were to heal for 100 and the user has 300% \c[4]REC\c[0], then the user is healed for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This is how effective items are when used by the user. The higher the \c[4]PHA\c[0] rate, the more effective the item effect. If the user is using a Potion that recovers 100% on a target ally and the user has 300% \c[4]PHA\c[0], then the target ally will receive healing for 300 instead.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]MP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will require to use. If the user has 100% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then the \c[4]MP\c[0] Cost will be standard. If the user has 50% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills that cost \c[4]MP\c[0] will cost only half the required \c[4]MP\c[0]. If the user has 200% \c[4]MCR\c[0], then all skills will cost 200% their \c[4]MP\c[0] cost.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much \c[4]TP\c[0] skills with an \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge when gaining \c[4]TP\c[0] through various actions. At 100%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge normally. At 50%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge at half speed. At 200%, \c[4]TP\c[0] will charge twice as fast.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from physical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]PDR\c[0], then all physical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>This rate affects how much damage the user will take from magical damage. If the user has 100% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then the user takes the normal amount. If the user has 50% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is halved. If the user has 200% \c[4]MDR\c[0], then all magical damage dealt to the user is doubled.

<WordWrap>On the field map, this alters how much damage the user will take when the player walks over a tile that damages the party. The \c[4]FDR\c[0] value only affects the damage dealt to the particular actor and not the whole party. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 100%, then the user takes the full damage. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 50%, then only half of the damage goes through. If \c[4]FDR\c[0] is at 200%, then floor damage is doubled for that actor.

<WordWrap>This determines the amount of experience gain the user whenever the user gains any kind of \c[4]EXP\c[0]. At 100% \c[4]EXR\c[0], the rate of experience gain is normal. At 50%, the experience gain is halved. At 200%, the experience gain for the user is doubled.

\>What \c[4]Status Menu Plugins\c[0] would you like to learn about?\<
<WordWrap>This plugin replaces the \c[4]Status Menu\c[0] with a whole new layout. Including the function to display more information regarding the actor.

<WordWrap>From it, you can display the current current stats and EXP for the actor, parameter gauge of the actor relative to other stats, the listed elements and their elemental rates, the listed states and their status infliction rates, the listed attribute rates.
<WordWrap>Ever wanted to display unique Game Variables into the status menu to portray your actors? Now you can!
<WordWrap>These variables can come from a global or individual source per actor.
<WordWrap>Variables listed in the Global Columns found in the parameters will be listed for all actors. Variables defined in the actor noteboxes will be listed for that actor when displayed.
<WordWrap>Ever wanted to log the battle statistics of your actors over the course of the entire gameplay? Well, now you can!
<WordWrap>It shows how many battles the actor was present in the starting party and what ratio.

<WordWrap>It also displays information about how many kills, deaths, and assists performed by the actor overall. Kills rise when the actor defeats an enemy. Deaths rise if the actor falls in battle. Assists rise if the actor is present during an enemy kill.
<WordWrap>It also shows the total amount of damage dealt, damage taken, healing dealt, and healing taken by the actor over the course of the game.

<WordWrap>This plugin adds a new '\c[4]Profile\c[0]' command to the \c[4]Status Menu\c[0] where the player can read up on the actor's biography. Pictures can be added in. Text can be updated mid-game, too!
<WordWrap>Some players may experience lag when walking near animated tiles. This is due to the fact that animated tiles constantly draw, delete, and redraw the tiles every few frames.
<WordWrap>Unfortunately, due to Pixi2's drawing method, there exists some memory leaks when this kind of drawing occurs.
<WordWrap>On mobile devices or weak computers with little memory to spare, this can potentially cause some games to crash.
<WordWrap>The option to enable/disable animated tiles is now in the options menu for players to toggle.
<WordWrap>This plugin allows you to set switches that are either always enabled or always disabled based on a various conditions.

<WordWrap>These conditions are here to help enable easier access to determining the lesser frequently seen flags set by the game such as determining if the game is running via debug mode or on a certain type of browser.
<WordWrap>Wanted to place an event in every single battle but copy/pasting it is too inefficient?
<WordWrap>Now, you can do it using \c[4]Base Troop Events\c[0], where every single battle takes a template of events from the selected troop you want it to!
<WordWrap>This plugin enables you to bind common events to the individual buttons on your keyboard.
<WordWrap>Instead of having the standard Z for OK and X for cancel, you can make other keys work differently.
<WordWrap>With the exception of important keys that shouldn't be altered, nearly full access is given across the span of the keyboard.
<WordWrap>Read more about how to set up this plugin in the plugin's own \c[4]Help File\c[0].
<WordWrap>The \c[4]Common Event Menu\c[0] allows you to create your own custom menu setups.
<WordWrap>When using it, you can list whatever common events you so wish and generate a menu that when selecting the menu command, it will run the common event.
<WordWrap>This common event menu setup allows you to utilize a help window, a picture window, and a subtext window to allow for your own personal touch when using the common event window.
<WordWrap>The \c[4]Common Event Menu Setup Packs\c[0] allow you to use premade menu settings to beautify your \c[4]Common Event Menus\c[0].
\>Which \c[4]Setup Pack\c[0] do you wish to look at?
<WordWrap>This plugin adds a '\c[4]Credits\c[0]' command to the title screen that will bring up a window of a credits page made the way you want.
<WordWrap>Text codes can be used for the credits page to allow for more customization options.
<WordWrap>Furthermore, specific entries can be tied to URL's so you can link back to those you've provided credit for!
<WordWrap>\c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] lacks the ability to toggle dashing on and off.
<WordWrap>This plugin will enable you to toggle dashing on and off as well as provide certain traits that will inhibit the party leader from being able to dash (such as an extra heavy weapon)
The wealth of knowledge here is astounding!
<WordWrap>The \c[4]Dash Toggle\c[0] plugin can turn \c[4]Dashing\c[0] on and off at a moment's notice. Do you wish to try it out?
<WordWrap>You should be able to dash to your heart's content right now.
<WordWrap>This function switches between having \c[4]Dashing\c[0] on or off.
<WordWrap>This plugin lets you place text above the heads of various events using a miniature label through a comment tag.
<WordWrap>The text used can also use text codes so text, icons, colors, etc. whatever it is, you can use it as a label!
<WordWrap>Have you ever imagined what it'd be like to live life without books? I certainly did and it wasn't a world I wanted to live in.

<WordWrap>You can try out the \c[4]Button Common Events\c[0] feature. Try pressing the O button to open up the \c[4]Options Menu\c[0]. Of course, this will have changed if you reconfigured the keyboard however.
<WordWrap>Add a way to access your website (or any) from within your game using this plugin!
<WordWrap>This plugin will also notify the player if the access attempt was also blocked.
I can just live here. Books are love. Books are life!

<WordWrap>\c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] is constructed in a way where each update to its engine is done once per frame update.
<WordWrap>While this is normally fine, as many players view the game through 60 fps, some players experience the game differently as their hardware may run at higher than 60 fps.
<WordWrap>When \c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] version 1.1.0 is implemented, it implemented \c[4]Galenmereth\c[0]’s \c[4]fluid timestep\c[0], which forces the game to always play as if it is 60 fps.
<WordWrap>In practice, this is great for everybody because players that experience more 60 fps will be able to play the game as if it was 60 fps.

<WordWrap>However, there comes a problem when a player’s hardware isn’t strong enough to support \c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] natively at 60 fps or if the player is using video recording software that goes below 60 fps.
<WordWrap>The game will appear laggy and jumping without good response rates from input commands or possibly even make the player miss out on certain visual frame updates.
<WordWrap>This plugin places a setting in the \c[4]Options\c[0] menu to enable or disable the fluid timestep addition and utilize the former \c[4]RPG Maker MV\c[0] engine updating function.
<WordWrap>This way, players will have the option of using \c[4]fluid timesteps\c[0] or opting to not use it instead of forcing it on everybody who may not be able to handle it.
<WordWrap>Sometimes there’s random jibber jabber that does not warrant a message box.
<WordWrap>The \c[4]Gab Window\c[0] fulfills that jibber jabber by placing such text outside of the message window box and at the corner of the screen.
<WordWrap>The gab text will appear briefly and then disappear, not showing up again until the gab text is updated with something else.

<WordWrap>This plugin allows players to change their keyboard configuration from the in-game \c[4]Options\c[0] menu provided that they're using a computer to play the game and not from a mobile device.
<WordWrap>The "\c[4]Keyboard Config\c[0]" option will send the player to a different screen where they can assign actions to each of the allowed keys on the keyboard.
<WordWrap>This plugin produces a window similar to that of the Select Item Window, but instead, it displays a list of skills from a designated actor and the skill type selected.
<WordWrap>When a skill is selected, it set the chosen variable's value to become that of the picked skill's ID.
<WordWrap>Pictures can function as something other than just a visual for your game. They can sometimes serve as UI elements or more!
<WordWrap>However, what they don’t have the ability to inherently do is to call upon common events when clicked on by the mouse.
<WordWrap>With this plugin, the pictures bound to a common event will become usable when clicked or touched!
I hope you are able to find everything with ease.
<WordWrap>Would you like to enable the \c[4]Picture Common Events\c[0] movement system?
<WordWrap>This is a reproduced method from \c[4]RPG Maker 2000\c[0] and \c[4]RPG Maker 2003\c[0].
<WordWrap>It allows the game to call a page’s events as if it were a common event.
<WordWrap>These events can be drawn from any event on any map within the game.
